loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario is 60 years old. She is a retired person and she needs a loan to fix up a room at her house because she wants to live in better conditions.

Rosario used to be a nurse. She is a divorced woman and she is the mother of three young people. She hopes you can help her because she is alone.

loans.use: to fix up a room at her house

loans.name: Hamadi

texts.en:
Hamadi, who is in his late 30's, is married with two children. One of them is in school and the other one is still small. Hamadi has been a tailor for six years now. He works from 8 AM to 10 PM daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Hamad’s third loans from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy two sewing machines and has paid back all his loans successfully.

He is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for the support of their group which is doing great. He can now make many suits and many dresses and can serve many customers.

He used the profit to pay school fees, repay the loan, take care of his family, and cover household expenses. He will use this loan to buy up-to-date materials and meet his customers’ demands and requests. He dreams of expanding his business.

Hamadi will make sure he pays back his loan within the loan scheduled time.

loans.use: to buy up-to-date materials for his tailoring business.

loans.name: Dionesia

texts.en: Most people in San Miguel have a thriving business farming rice. Dionesia is also engaged in this business to provide for her seven children. She is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and to pay for other farmers. With these inputs, she will be able to increase her yield. Farming rice provides her family the needed rice to eat and also an income for household expenses and education for her youngest child.  Dionesia is 56 years old and has a 14-year-old dependent.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and to pay for other farmers.

loans.name: Madelyn

texts.en:
Madelyn is 29 years old. She is married and has two children to provide for. Madelyn has been earning well in selling primary goods in their local community. For more than three years, this has covered their daily needs, and she considered it as their main source of income.

She joined and gained access to GDMPC and needs some financial assistance. Recently, she took a new loan for the purpose of buying more goods to sell such as canned goods, noodles, coffee, and sugar.

She wants to improve her grocery store to ensure a better source of income for the family in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell.

loans.name: Peguaho Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama Peguaho, está en su ciclo uno, es un grupo nuevo que está trabajando de manera unida para poder mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus seres queridos. Ellas son luchadoras y cada una está poniendo su mejor esfuerzo para poder crecer y salir adelante.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Julia quien a través del esfuerzo y el trabajo continuo que está haciendo por medio de la venta de animales que hace, está luchando para poder dar a sus seres queridos todo lo que ellos no pudieron tener. Ella es una mujer muy emprendedora que poco a poco quiere crecer para poder mejorar la vida de su familia.
La Sra. Julia solicita de este préstamo para la compra de animales para su posterior venta, como ser, cerdos y otros, y de esa manera poder seguir luchando y esforzándose por mejorar.
texts.en:
The group is called Peguah and it is in its first cycle.  It is a new group working in unity to improve the lives of their loved ones. They are fighters and everyone is putting their best effort to grow and succeed.

One of the members is Julia who through her own efforts and continuous work with the sale of animals, is striving to provide her loved ones with everything that she was not able to have.

She is a very enterprising woman who wants to gradually grow to be able to improve the lives of her family.

Julia is requesting this loan for the purchase of animals for subsequent resale, such as pigs and others, and thus to be able to continue fighting and striving to improve.

loans.use: to purchase animals for breeding and subsequent sale.

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Abra est une femme mariée âgée de 20 ans qui vit avec son enfant à charge à Adidogomé. Abra est une revendeuse de de sucre en détail qui s’approvisionne deux fois par mois au marché et le revend en circulant dans les quartiers environnant. Abra sollicite l’octroi de ce prêt pour commander des des sacs de sucre en vue d’agrandir son stock et mieux vendre afin de gagner des bénéfices pour pouvoir aider son mari à bien organiser l’éducation scolaire de leur enfant.
texts.en:
Abra, age 20, is a married woman with one dependent child who lives in Adidogomé. She is a retailer of sugar. She stocks up twice a month at the market, and she conducts her sales as an itinerant vendor in neighboring districts.

Abra is seeking this loan to purchase sacks of sugar. She wants to bolster her stock and improve her sales. Increased profits will help her to support her husband in planning for their child's education.

loans.use: to buy 2 sacks of sugar.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana vive en la Ciudad de Encarnación, es jubilada, pero para seguir ganándose un dinero extra para su familia, montó una cantina hace ya más de 8 años ya en el rubro.
Ella es una persona que se esfuerza para poder seguir trabajando y dando a su familia todo para tener una vida digna y sin privaciones. Pide este préstamo para la compra de una heladera para su negocio, y de esa forma poder seguir con sus ventas.
texts.en:
Juana lives in the city of Encarnación.  She is retired, but in order to continue to earn a bit of extra money for her family, she set up a bar in the area over eight years ago.

She is a person who strives to keep working in order to provide for her family, and to have a decent life without hardship. 

She is requesting this loan to purchase a refrigerator for her business, and thus able to continue with her sales.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a single woman. She has two children.

She operates a food café. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a good area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy utensils and stock of ingredients for preparing food. She hopes that in the future, she will expand business. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy utensils and stock of ingredients for preparing food

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Debora, who is in her late 30's, is single with two kids who are still in school. She has been selling fish for seven years now. She works from 2 PM to 10 PM daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Debora's eleventh loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase fish stock and has managed to pay back all her loans successfully. She is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for the support of their group which is doing great.

She used the profit to build a house, buy a plot of land, pay school fees, reinvest in the business, and take care of her family. She will use this loan to expand her business by increasing the fish stock to meet her customers' requests.

She dreams of owning a house and butcher shop. Debora will make sure she pays back her loan within the loan scheduled time.

loans.use: to expanding her business by increasing the fish stock to meet her customers' requests.

loans.name: Mujeres Alegres Group

texts.es:
El grupo está integrado por 17 mujeres, todas ellas de la ciudad de Encarnación, son mujeres muy sacrificadas que quieren mejorar sus condiciones de vida y es por eso que luchan. Están dentro del programa de eliminación de la pobreza esforzándose por mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de sus seres queridos.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Norma quien es una persona muy trabajadora, ella trabaja de empleada doméstica  y  vende ropas de forma ambulante, es una mujer muy sacrificada que se esfuerza el doble para garantizar  a sus seres queridos una vida digna.
Pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en la compra de ropas variadas para la venta, como ser remeras, jeans, camisas, pantalones y otro tipo de prendas, y de esa forma poder continuar con sus ventas como lo viene haciendo. Agradecen por la oportunidad que reciben de poder mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
The group is composed of 17 women, all from the city of Encarnacion.  

They are hard working women who want to improve their living conditions and that is what they strive for. 

They are in the program of poverty eradication efforts to improve their living conditions and those of their loved ones.

One of the members is Norma who is a hard worker.  She works as a maid and also sells clothes door to door.  She is a very giving woman who works twice as hard in order to ensure her loved ones have a dignified life.

She is requesting this loan to invest in the purchase of various clothes for sale, such as t-shirts, jeans, shirts, pants and other clothing, and thus be able to continue with her sales as she has done so far. 

They are grateful for the opportunity being given to be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for sale, such as: t-shirts, jeans, shirts, pants and other types of clothing.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is in her late 30's and is married with two children. One is in school and the other one is still small. She has been running a business of a beauty salon for nine years now. She works from 8 AM to 9 PM daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Christina's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the salon products and to start selling hand bags, shoes, and fabrics. She has managed to pay back all her loans successfully.

She used the profit to pay school fees, to repay the loan, to reinvest in the business, and to cover household expenses. She will use this loan to buy up-to-date salon products and to increase the shoe, bags and fabrics. She dreams of opening another salon in a different place.

Christina will be accountable for paying back her loan.

loans.use: to buy up-to-date salon products and to increase the shoes, bags, and fabrics to sell.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is married and has four adult-aged children. Norma owns and operates a a rice farm just to earn a living. For many years in farming, she has been providing for the needs of the family and was able to send her children to school.

She joined and gained access to GDMPC. Recently, she took out a loan to purchase organic fertilizer for her rice in order to produce a good quality of rice in the market that will result in greater income.

Improving their farm is her plan because it is their main source of income, and she wants to ensure a better living and meet the educational needs of her children when they get into college.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for her rice field.

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel is a 24 years old, still single and living in Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She helps her parents in providing the daily expenses of their family, and in order to help them, she is engaged in buying-and-selling businesses.

Hazel is asking for financial assistance, and recently she took a loan from GDMPC to purchase a variety of fish to sell it to their local community members. She is indeed hoping to have a better living with her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of fish to sell in the market.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne is a single woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be honest.

She operates a tailoring business where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her primary customers are regular.

She will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her living standards. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en:
Touch is a married mother of two school children and a young kid who is underage for school, living in Kampong Cham province, and she is 32 years old.

To make a living, she has grown cassava and rice for 14 years. Her crop has not grown well recently, so she could not produce high yields as before. Her income is about 7 USD per day. After expenses, she is able to save around 3 USD each day for emergency needs.

Touch can upgrade her family’s living from a previous loan and this is her second loan with VisionFund. As a group leader of two, she is going to manage her portion of the loan in order to buy fertilizer and pesticide to increase the crop productivity, and the rest of the money will pay for school fees to support her children’s education.

She hopes to earn income so that she can keep her children in school until their graduation and get a good job in the future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide to increase crop productivity as well as her income to save for supporting her children's studying.

loans.name: Cheun's Group

texts.en:
Married with six children, two of whom are in school, Cheun is a local farmer living in Battambang province, where she and her husband are growing rice for the main source of their income for years. Additional income for the family comes from working for others for fees. The challenge to her businesses is lack of working capital.

Cheun has already been with VisionFund for eight loan times already and she has paid back completely. Past loans have helped her to send her children to school and buy them school supplies. In the group of two members, she is the group leader and she will use her loan to buy rice seeds, organic pesticide and organic fertilizer to boost the crop yields.

She hopes that she can generate more income to keep sending her children to school and upgrade their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds, organic pesticide and organic fertilizer to boost the crop yields so as to keep sending her children to school.

loans.name: Filemon

texts.es:
El Sr. Filemon es de la ciudad de Santaní, él es dueño de un taller de chapería y pinturas, con 5 años de funcionamiento, tiene muy buena cantidad de clientes que siempre se acerca a su taller.
Él es muy conocido del lugar, cuenta con clientela formada, y se esfuerza para poder crecer cada día. Solicita este préstamo para poder invertirlo en la  compras de materiales para usar en su negocio de chapería, como masillas, pinturas, pinceles y otros.
texts.en:
Filemon is from Santaní city.  He owns a bodywork (car) and paint workshop and it has been in operation for five years.

He has a very good number of customers who always approach his workshop.

He is well-known in the area, and he has a well established clientele.  He strives for his business to grow every day. 

He is requesting this loan to invest in the purchase of materials for use in his bodywork such as putties, paint, brushes and others.

loans.use: to purchase puttys, paints, brushes and others to use in bodywork (car) and paint business.

loans.name: Labito

texts.en: Labito is 52 years old and from the town of Bien Unido, Bohol. He has been a fisherman for two decades now. This livelihood allows him to provide for his family and two dependents ages 14 and 19. He would like to make some changes and improvements to his fishing business. He is asking for a loan of PHP 18,000 to buy a new fishing net and an engine for the boat. This in turn will boost his productivity and increase his income. His profit will be for food and school fees for his children.

loans.use: to buy a new fishing net and engine for his boat

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be ambitious.

She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, cooking oil, bread, soap, flour, and other items. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transport.

She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, cooking oil, bread, flour, and other items. Her business goal is to expand her business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children to university level.

This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stock.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, cooking oil, bread, flour, and other items.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is grateful that she was granted a number of loans in the past which she has fully repaid on time. Those loans definitely helped sustain and grow her pineapple farm. Her farm means a lot to her for it is where she gets funds to support her family and meet their daily basic needs. Life maybe hard at times but God has been faithful to her family.

She trusts that she will again avail a PHP 25,000 loan which she will use to buy fertilizers for a more productive harvest of her crops and partly to pay for her laborers at her farm. Although there are times that her harvest is little, she maintains her strong faith that God will supply all their needs.

Alma dreams for her farm to grow and flourish. She trusts for continued blessings on her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and farm inputs for a more productive corn harvest.

loans.name: Clerk

texts.en:
Clerk is a married man. He has five children. He describes himself to be ambitious.

He operates a retail business where he sells cereals. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in a busy area and his primary customers are locals.

He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of maize and beans. His business goal is to be a supplier within five years. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of maize and beans

loans.name: Deodita

texts.en:
Deodita is married and has 4 children. She helps her husband with their fishing business which they have sustained for many years, the business is doing well. She wants to expand her business and improve their living conditions. She asks for financial support from GDMPC to buy additional fishing nets and hooks.

Deodita's plan for the future is to save more money for the educational needs of their children.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing nets and hooks

loans.name: Sreynech

texts.en:
Sreynech is a 19-year-old single university student who resides in Phnom Penh city.

Sreynech has an opportunity for an internship abroad for nine months, during which she will get a salary which is enough to live and save about 9 USD each day.

She does not have the funds to prepare some important travel documents. She requests a Kiva loan via VisionFund to prepare a Visa, passport, and other study materials.

She hopes that this loan and internship will provide experiences and pave the way to a good job in the future.

loans.use: to prepare Visa, passport, and other study materials to support her internship.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma has run a fish-selling business for many years. Her husband is a fisherman and she sells fish in their village. She earns a good income which sustains their living and pays for the educational needs of her children. She was able to repay her previous loan from GDMPC that she used to purchase a fishing boat. To improve the business, she took a new loan to purchase fishing nets.

She wishes to expand her business and save money to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets

loans.name: Arouwatou

texts.fr: Arowatou est une femme mariée habitant à Adidogomé et qui avec deux enfants à sa charge. Agée de 36 ans, Arowatou est une marchande de produits de beauté qui le vend dans sa boutique et en parcourant les quartiers environnant. Arowatou fait son approvisionnement une fois par mois au marché et désire ce prêt pour commander des boîtes de pommades en vue d’en tirer un maximum de profit afin de pouvoir subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et améliorer leur condition de vie quotidienne.
texts.en:
Arowatou, age 36, is married with two dependent children. She lives in Adidogomé.

Arowatou is a reseller of beauty products. She sells out of her shop and as an itinerant vendor around neighboring districts. She stocks up once a month at the market.

Arowatou is seeking this loan to purchase cartons of pomade. Her goal is to maximize her profits in order to better provide for her children's needs and improve their day-to-day quality of life.

loans.use: to buy 50 cartons of pomade.

loans.name: Ren

texts.en:
Ren, aged 41, is a rice farmer from Kratie province and a married mother of four dependent children, two of whom are still in school. Income of this family comes from rice growing, the main business, and grocery selling, the secondary business. She has been involved in the farming business for 23 years and she earns about USD 12 per day and can save about USD 7 per day. There is not enough water to supply the rice farm and this is the main challenge to her rice farming business.

Ren is new to VisionFund and she is now applying for a loan to support her rice farming business by purchasing rice seeds, organic fertilizer and organic pesticide. She hopes that she can get more yields to improve their living conditions, to buy household supplies and to buy school materials for the children.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and organic fertilizer to support her rice farming business so as to be able to buy household supplies for her family and school materials for her children.

loans.name: Mercilyn

texts.en: Mercilyn is a mother with two children. She lives in Trinidad, Bohol. She grows rice for additional income. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer to sustain her farm. Mercilyn hopes that someday she can also find other business opportunities so she can successfully send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
Marisa lives in Misamis Occidental. She and her husband provide transportation services to support the needs of their family. She has done this for six years and has a good income from this business. There’s nothing more that can make her happy, except to see her children be successful in their studies. Marisa borrowed a new loan from GDMPC to repair the vehicle used in her business.

Marisa's plan in the future is to save more money and to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy new tires and brake pads

loans.name: Ruos' Group

texts.en:
Ruos is a 34-year-old farmer from in Kratie province. He is married and has three children, one attends school.

He has grown cassava and rice for ten years to earn income for his family. He sometimes works as a paid worker for additional income. The drop of cassava prices is the main challenge to his business. Ruos earns about $17 USD per day and can save about $14 USD each day after daily expenses.

He has formed a two-member group to apply for a loan from VisionFund to buy organic pesticide and organic fertilizer to support his farming. He hopes that the cassava will grow well and return good yields which would enable him to expand his business and send his children to school.

loans.use: to buy organic pesticide and organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Langheng

texts.en:
Langheng is a 22-year-old university student who resides in Kandal province. He will participate in an internship abroad for nine months and during these months, will receive $ 10 USD per day. He needs the funds to prepare important documents to travel abroad. He is applying for a Kiva loan via VisionFund to pay for a passport and visa to support his internship.

He hopes that this loan will help him to improve his skills and gain more experiences.

loans.use: to pay for preparing a passport and visa to support on his internship.

loans.name: Isidro

texts.es:
El señor Isidro, es de la ciudad de Santaní, es una persona muy trabajadora, se dedica a la agricultura, tiene cultivos diversos, también trabaja en ventas ambulantes, es un señor muy responsable y muy trabajador.
Comenta que a través de su trabajo se gana la vida de una manera digna y honesta y ayuda a su familia.
Pide este préstamo para poder comprar productos varios para la venta, como ser prendas, calzados, artículos de bazar y otros.
texts.en:
Isidro is from the city of Santaní. He is a very hardworking person. He works in agriculture growing various crops. He also works as a street vendor. He is very responsible and hardworking.

He says that through his work he earns dignified and honest earnings to support his family.

He is asking for this loan in order to buy various products to sell, such as garments, shoes, bazaar items and more.

loans.use: to buy various products to sell, such as garments, shoes, bazaar items and more.

loans.name: Gyanu

texts.en:
Gyanu, 50 years old, is married and has two children. Many years ago, she established her grocery shop business. Working seven days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family.

She has already received and successfully repaid four loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods. In the future, Gyanu plans to uplift her family's economic condition. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.

While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase supplies for screen printing, such as: fabrics, paints, brushes and other

loans.name: Mana

texts.en:
Mana, 48 years old, is married and has two children. Many years ago, Mana established her grocery shop business. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy grocery goods. In the future, she plans to uplift her family's economic conditions. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods.

loans.name: 10 De Agosto Group

texts.es:
El grupo 10 de Agosto está en su ciclo número 2 del programa de comité de mujeres, donde todas están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza. Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Gladys; quien a través del esfuerzo, el trabajo continuo se gana la vida.
Gladys se dedica a sus ventas en forma ambulante de frutas y verduras, es una mujer muy sacrificada que se esfuerza por poder dar a su familia una vida digna y sin privaciones.
La Sra. Gladys solicita de este préstamo para la compra de los productos como por ejemplo lechugas, cebollitas, naranjas, manzanas. Maneja bien su negocio para que de esa manera también pueda tener mejores  ingresos.
texts.en:
The group 10 de Agosto is in its second cycle of the women's committee program where they are all participating in a survey on poverty elimination. One of the members is Gladys, who makes a living through effort and ongoing work.

Gladys makes a living selling fruits and vegetables as a street vendor. She is a very selfless woman who exerts herself in order to be able to give her family a life that is dignified and without hardships.

Gladys is requesting this loan for the purchase of the products. For example, lettuce, onions, oranges, and apples. She manages her business well so that in this way she can also have a better income.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell like lettuce, onions, oranges, apples and others.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be innovative. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 11 years. Her business is located in a good place and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stock

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more supplies for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Sopheab's Group

texts.en:
Sopheab is a 42-year-old married woman with 3 children, all attend school. She is a resident in Mondulkiri province.

Sopheab and her husband grow cassava for the main source of income and raise pigs to earn additional income. Cassava is being threatened by diseases and the yield is low. These are the main obstacles to the success of her cassava farming business.

She decided to form a 3-member group to apply for a loan from VisionFund, this is her first time. As the group leader, she will use her loan to buy organic fertilizer to remove weeds from her farmland. She hopes that the crop will grow and produce high outputs. She would like to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy organic pesticides to remove weeds.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en: Nelly is a married woman. She has six children. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a pharmacy. She has been involved in this business for seven years. Her business is located in a good place and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be low stock. She will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy more stock of medicine. She hopes that in the future, she will have an improved life. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of medicine.

loans.name: Ratreysreytoch

texts.en:
Ratreysreytoch is a 19-year-old university student who resides in Phnom Penh city. She has an opportunity for an internship abroad for nine months. She will receive some money which is enough to support her living and savings of $10 USD per day.

She does not have the funds to prepare important travel documents. She is applying for a Kiva loan via VisionFund to pay for her passport and visa to support the internship. She hopes that this loan will help her to improve her skills and gain valuable experiences.

loans.use: to pay for a passport and visa to support her internship.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita has been earning from raising her pigs well to sell to the market, and she has been doing this for many years. She takes her time in taking good care of her pigs and it is her desire to improve and expand her business. She has successfully repaid her previous loan used for the business. Recently, she took a new loan to buy feeding supplies for her piglets. She plans to expand her piggery to gain more profit for a better future.

loans.use: to buy feeding supplies for her piglets

loans.name: Analie

texts.en: Analie is a 26-year-old mother of one. She and her family live in Bien Unido, Bohol. While she helps her husband in their fishing business, she also sells cosmetics from Avon. She is asking for a loan to pay for fishing boat repair and to buy more lotion and cosmetics from Avon. She is determined to work hard so she can send her child to school someday.

loans.use: to pay for fishing boat repair and to buy lotion and cosmetics.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
The dark-green color liquid resembles Pepsi soft drinks but it is not. Instead, Anita uses the empty Pepsi bottles for gasoline. She has had the business for a year and earns 1,100 PHP per month. Anita will use the loan to buy gasoline to sell in her town of San Miguel.

She hope that by expanding her business, she will be able to support her four children's education. Anita plans to have another business venture.

loans.use: to  buy more gasoline

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Henry is a male Kiva borrower. He describes himself to be responsible. He operates a dairy farm. His primary customers are locals. He will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy a 10,000 litre water tank to store clean water for domestic use. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a 10,000 litre water tank

loans.name: Phat's Group

texts.en:
A local farmer living in Kampong Cham province, Phat is 28 years old and married. She is blessed with two dependent children, one of whom is in school. To make a living, she and her husband are growing rice on a one-hectare area of farmland, and they work as paid workers to earn additional income.

They have been involved in the farming business for years and they earn around USD 17 per day and can save around USD 10 per day. The challenge to her rice farming business is that the rice crop is being severely threatened by pests, which results in low output production.

Phat is a first-time borrower with VisionFund Cambodia. In this group of five members, she is the group leader. Phat will use her loan to buy rice seeds and organic fertilizer to improve her farm's output. She hopes that she can have enough capital to expand her business and to support her children’s studying until they graduate.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and organic fertilizer to improve her farm's output so as to support her children’s studying until they graduate.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: San Pablo Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se formó en Ciudad del Este, es un comité nuevo que se unió para que cada una pueda crecer y mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de sus seres queridos. Ellas luchan por un mejor porvenir para sus familias, para poder darles una vida digna.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Andrea quien vende ropas variadas de manera ambulante, está poniendo su mayor esfuerzo para poder mejorar poco a poco por medio de su trabajo. Comenta que aunque ha tenido muchas dificultades se esfuerza para poder crecer y salir adelante.
Pide este préstamo para poder comprar prendas variadas, como ser: remeras, jeans, camisas, pantalones y otros, y de esta forma poder seguir con sus ventas como lo viene haciendo, ella es una persona muy sacrificada y luchadora.
texts.en:
This group started in the Ciudad del Este. It is a new communal bank that came together so that each one can grow and improve their living conditions and that of their loved ones. They fight for a better future for their families, in order to give them a decent life.

One of the members is Andrea who sells various clothing as a street vendor. She is making her best effort to improve little by little through her work. She says that although she has many difficulties she strives to grow and get ahead.

She is asking for this loan in order to buy various clothing such as: t-shirts, jeans, shirts, pants, and more so she can continue with her sales as she has been doing. She is self-sacrificing and a fighter.

loans.use: to buy various pieces of clothing to sell such as: t-shirts, jeans, shirts, pants, and more.

loans.name: Kaaguy Poty Group

texts.es:
El comité se llama Kaaguy Poty es un grupo bastante sólido integrado por señoras muy guapas y emprendedoras de la ciudad de Santaní, son de una zona rural, que aún está en crecimiento, donde todas las integrantes luchan por sus familias.
Se destaca en este grupo el trabajo en equipo muy bien encaminado, teniendo como pilar el compromiso y la solidaridad por todas las integrantes del comité.  Todas las integrantes de este grupo se dedican a actividades rurales como la cría y venta de animales, pero entre ellas se destaca la Sra. Joaquina, quien por medio de la cría de cerdos, gallinas, y otros animales, tiene los medios para poder ayudar a su familia.
Pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en la compra de animales para la cría, y también de balanceados para poder seguir con su pequeño emprendimiento que le ayuda a mantener  a su familia.
texts.en:
This group is called Kaaguy Poty. It is quite a strong group made up of very beautiful and entrepreneurial women in the city of Santaní. They are from a rural area, although it is growing, where all of the members fight for their families.
What stands out about this group is their teamwork which is very well directed. They have as a pillar the commitment and solidarity of all members. All of the members of this group earn a living in rural activities like the breeding and selling of animals. Among them is Joaquina, who through breeding pigs, hens and other animals, has the means to be able to help her family.
She is asking for this loan to be able to invest it in buying animals and also buying animal feed to be able to continue with her small business that helps her to sustain her family.

loans.use: to buy animals for breeding and animal feed.

loans.name: Nirout

texts.en:
This young university student, whose name is Nirout, is 21 years old. Nowadays, he resides in Prey Veng province. Recently, he has passed to go to an internship abroad for nine months. During these months, he will get around 12 USD per day.

Having not enough working capital to prepare some important documents to travel abroad is the main challenge for him. Because of this reason, he is now applying for a Kiva loan in the amount 1,270 USD via VisionFund Cambodia to pay for preparing his passport and visa to support his internship.

He hopes that this loan will help him to improve his skills so that he can get a good job in the future.

loans.use: to pay for preparing his passport and visa to support his internship and to improve his skills so that he can get a good job in the future.

location.town: Prey Veng province, Me sang district

loans.name: Damas Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
Estas señoras de la ciudad de San Ignacio se unieron para poder mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de sus seres queridos, ellas son unidas y solidarias entre ellas, trabajan juntas en actividades para poder mejorar.
La Señora Maria es comerciante, tiene un kiosco, vive con su marido e hijos en casa propia que con sacrificio han podido tener. Maria está poniendo su mayor esfuerzo para poder mejorar sus condiciones de vida, y dar a su familia todo lo que ella no pudo tener.
Ella desea invertir su préstamo para aumentar sus ingresos, y poder comprar golosinas, bebidas, galletitas y otros, y de esa forma poder seguir con sus ventas como lo viene haciendo. Agradece por esta oportunidad que recibe de poder crecer y mejorar.
texts.en:
These women from the city of San Ignacio came together to improve their living conditions and those of their loved ones. They are united and supportive of each other. They work together on jobs to be able to improve.

Maria is a business woman and has a kiosk. She lives with her husband and children in her own house which they have been able to have through sacrifice. Maria is putting in the greatest effort in order to be able to improve her living conditions and give her family everything that she could not have.

She wishes to invest her loan to increase her income and be able to buy candies, drinks, cookies and others and in this way be able to continue with her sales the way she has been. She is grateful for this opportunity she is receiving to be able to grow and improve.

loans.use: to buy candies, drinks, cookies and other products to stock her kiosk.

loans.name: Tufaidi Group

texts.en:
Hadija who is in her early 30's is single with three children, one of them is still small and the others are in school. She has been selling charcoal for eight years now. She works from 07am to 07pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Hadija's 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increasing on charcoal stock and has managed to pay back her loan successfully. She is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for the support of their group which is doing great. She used the profit to pay school fees,loan repayment and covered household expenses. She will use this loan to buy sacks of charcoal to resale. She dreams of building her house and to take her children to good school.

Hadija will share this loan with her loan group Tufaidi which has five members who will hold each accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal and to resale

loans.name: San Rafael Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama San Rafael integrado por 16 mujeres ,están luchando por mejorar sus condiciones de vida a través del trabajo unido y del programa de eliminación de la pobreza.
Una de las integrantes es la Señora Tomasa, quien tiene una despensa en la que todos los días trabaja desde muy tempranas horas del día, hasta tarde en la noche. Tomasa lucha por su familia para poder darles una buena calidad de vida, ya que no quiere que pasen por necesidades como las que ella tuvo que pasar.
Pide este préstamo para poder comprar insumos para surtir su despensa, como ser bebidas carne, panificados y otros productos, y así seguir dando a sus clientes lo que solicitan.
texts.en:
This group is called San Rafael and is made up of 16 women who are fighting to improve their living conditions by working together and through the poverty elimination programme.

One of the members is called Tomasa. She has a small grocery store in which she works every day from very early in the morning to very late at night. Tomasa fights for her family to be able to give them a good quality of life as she does not want them to lack the necessities that she did.

She is asking for this loan to be able to buy supplies to stock up her grocery store such as drinks, meat, baked goods and other products and thus continue meeting her customers needs.

loans.use: to buy supplies for their small grocery store such as drinks, meat, baked goods and other products.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 41 years old, married, and has four children. She owns and manages her own farm. This is the only thing that they have in order for them to earn and to be able to provide for their daily needs.

With the help of her husband, who will be the one who helps her on the farm, she decided to borrow a loan to purchase fertilizer for her rice field in order to produce and deliver plenty of rice in the market.

Jocelyn’s plan for her future is to save money to sustain their daily needs and for the education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for her rice field production.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en: Carolyne is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, soda, bread, flour, and other items. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy more stock of soap, flour, soda, bread, and other items. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to puchase additional inventory.

loans.use: to buy more stock of soap, flour, soda, bread, and other items.

loans.name: Neriza

texts.en:
Neriza is grateful for KIVA's and CCT's continuous moral and financial support. The previous loans that have been granted to her have sustained her general store and helped with daily expenses.

She requests 15,000 PHP to purchase rice, instant noodles, canned goods, eggs, oil, coffee, and toiletries. Her store means a lot to her and has been her source of income for twenty years. Although there are times she encounters difficulty collecting her receivables, she was not discouraged but continued to trust the Lord for their daily needs.

Neriza's dream is to expand her store to become a big grocery store. She prays for abundance and good health for her family. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

*All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Navy

texts.en:
A 48-year-old married woman, Navy is a resident of Kampong Thom Province. She has four children, two of whom are still in school.

In order to better support her family, Navy is growing rice while her husband is working as a construction worker. Earning about USD 10 per day, Navy can manage to save about USD 5 each day after daily expenses.

This will be her second loan with VisionFund Cambodia. The past loan enabled her to send her children to school. Navy will use this loan to pay for school tuition fees for her son. She hopes that her son can graduate from university and have a well-paid job.

loans.use: to pay school tuition fees for her son so that he can pursue studying and get a well-paid job after graduating from university.

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en: Maurice is a married man with 4 children who describes himself as a risk taker. He has made metal boxes for 4 years. His business is located in a competitive area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. He will use the 50,000 KES loan to pay school fees for his children. He hopes that in the future, he will have increased profits. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to expand his business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en: Zawadi is a married woman with 6 children. She has operated a retail business to sell coconuts for 6 years. Her primary customers are local buyers. She describes her biggest business challenge as low stock. She will use the 40,000 KES loan to buy more coconuts. She hopes that in the future to expand her business. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to buy a vehicle to transport the coconuts.

loans.use: to buy coconuts.

loans.name: Evan

texts.en:
Evan is an honest man who has seven children, all of whom are in school. He is a tea farmer who works eight hours a day on his plantation as well as cares for the cattle he is raising as a side business. He must deal with the challenge of pests and diseases that affects his fields. Once he harvests his tea, he sells it to tea factories in the Bushenyi district in Uganda.

Evan took out and successfully repaid his previous loan of 2,000,000 UGX through Kiva's field partner UGAFODE, which helped him to increase his yields. He has now applied for a 5,000,000 UGX loan to buy manure for his plantation and prune the old tea trees, which will encourage more growth.

Evan intends to use his profits to start building a bigger residential house for his family since the current one is too small to be housing his large family plus a dependent. He promises to repay promptly in order to uphold the good relationship he is enjoying with UGAFODE and Kiva lenders.

Evan’s vision is to buy a large piece of land so that he can increase his cultivation. He wishes to thank Kiva lenders for their generosity.

loans.use: to buy manure for his plantation and prune the old tea trees.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
This young university student, whose name is Sam, is 20 years old. Nowadays, he resides in Steung Meanchey district, Phnom Penh city. Recently, he has passed to go to an internship abroad for nine months. During these months, he will get an amount of money that is enough for him to support his living and be able to save about 5 USD per day.

Having not enough working capital to prepare some important documents to travel to abroad is the main challenge for him. Because of this reason, he is now applying for a Kiva loan for the amount 800 USD via VisionFund Cambodia to pay for preparing his passport and visa to support his internship. He hopes that this loan will help him to improve his skills so that he can get a good job in the future.

loans.use: to pay for preparing his passport and visa, to support his internship, and to improve his skills.

loans.name: Edison

texts.en:
Edison is a 36-year-old man applying for a loan of 2,500,000 UGX. This is his first loan from UGAFODE MDI. He is married and his children are 6 and 2 years old.

He raises poultry and works 12 hours a day. He earns additional income growing bananas. He started this business in 2013 in Irashaniro village, Kibaare. He started these businesses to raise money to improve his family's life style.

He will use this loan to buy chicken mash for his birds. He sells mostly to hotels and schools. His dreams having as many birds as he can. The main challenge is pests and diseases that affect his poultry. He is honest and he says UGAFODE MDI staff provide good customer service.

loans.use: to buy poultry feed.

loans.name: Jean Alex

texts.en:
Jean is a repeat customer applying for a loan of 4,000,000 UGX. She is a married 43-year-old woman in her fourth loan cycle from UGAFODE MDI. She has three children, all attend school.

She has grown and sold bananas since 2008 and works 8 hours a day. She started the business to raise money to educate her children. She will use this loan to service her car and buy mulch for her banana plantation. Her dream is to educate her children and have working capital. She is an honest woman.

loans.use: To buy mulch

loans.name: Ananta Kumari

texts.en:
Ananta is 46 years old. She is married and has one children. Many years ago, she established her produce and vegetable sales business. Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid six loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy pesticides and seeds. In the future, Ananta plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buy pesticides and seeds

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is married and has three children. For the past eight years he has operated a store where he sells clothes. His store is located in a residential area, and his primary customers are locals. His biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital to expand his enterprise.

This will be James’ first loan with Kiva's field partner SMEP Microfinance Bank. He has applied for 50,000 KES to buy more inventory. He will use his anticipated profits to buy additional clothes to sell.

James' business goal is to open another shop within five years.

loans.use: to buy more inventory for his clothing store.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a married man. He has 4 children. He describes himself to be honest. He operates a retail business where he sells clothes and cereals. He has been involved in this business for 4 years. His business is located in a busy area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be Inadequate Working Capital. He will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes, cereals. His business goal is to expand business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes, cereals

loans.name: Esterluna

texts.en:
Esterluna is a 28-year-old woman who lives with her family in Catigbian, Bohol. She and her husband are engaged in a hog-raising business. They also buy and sell pigs as well. They have been doing this business for six years to earn a living. They work hard together to raise their three children, ages 11, 6, and 1 year.

Thus, Esterluna is asking for a loan to buy more pigs to sell. She wishes to improve their business in the future to have a sustainable means of living.

loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena has received a number of loans in the past, which have certainly helped sustain her general store and thus helped in their daily sustenance. She thanks CCT and Kiva for their noble missions and objectives.

She trusts that she can again access a PHP 25,000 loan to refill her store with food and household items such as rice, instant noodles, canned goods, beverages, fruits, and toiletries. Her store means a lot to her, since it has been her source of income for the past twelve years and sustained her family's basic needs. Although there are times she encounters difficulty collecting her receivables, she maintained her positive attitude that better days are ahead.

Elena dreams of having her own vehicle to transport fruits and veggies from farm owners. She wants her children to finish college, since she believes that education is a path to a better future for her children. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more fruits (mostly bananas) and grocery items to sell at her small store.

loans.name: Abra Woevi

texts.fr: Abra est une femme mariée qui vit avec son enfant à charge à Adidogomé. Agée de 29 ans, Abra est une revendeuse des habits de friperies qui s’approvisionne une fois par mois au marché et le revend en parcourant les quartiers environnant. Pour avoir un stock important et maximiser son profit afin de répondre à nombreuse attentes de ses clients, Abra demande ce crédit pour commander des unités de jupes et tricots de friperies en vue de gagner des bénéfices et venir en aide à  son mari aux diverses charges quotidiennes éprouvées par la famille.
texts.en:
Abra is a married woman who lives with her child in her care in Adidogomé. Abra is 29 years old and a retailer of secondhand clothing who gets her supplies once per month from the market and sells them throughout the surrounding neighborhoods.

In order to have a large stock, maximize her profit, and meet her clients' numerous expectations, Abra is requesting this loan to purchase secondhand skirts and sweaters with the goal of earning a profit and assisting her husband with the various day-to-day expenses the family encounters.

loans.use: to purchase 100 skirts and 200 sweaters.

loans.name: Israfil

texts.en:
Israfil is living in the Mahmudlu village of the Fuzuli region with his lovely family. He is married and has three children. His children are in the secondary school. His wife is a nurse and she cares for patients. He is an IDP (internally displaced persons) from the town of Fuzuli. Israfil has been in the agriculture business for many years, now he has also sheep and cattle.

Israfil loves his work and is always looking for ways to develop his business. He has applied to Komak company. Currently, he needs his fourth loan in the amount of 2000 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat). With this loan he wants to build a small stall for his sheep.

loans.use: to build a small stall for sheep

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a Kiva borrower. He describes himself to be focused. He operates a barber shop and a beauty salon. He has been involved in this business for 4 years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be small business space.

He will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy shaving machine and beauty products for the salon. His business goal is to have more business outlets within 5 years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy shaving machine and beauty products for the salon

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with two children. When asked, she described herself as honest.

For the past two years Mary has operated a shop where she sells sugar, sodas, bread, flour and other groceries to the local population. Her biggest business challenge is her inability to have greater stock on hand.

Mary has taken out and successfully repaid two previous loans through Kiva's field partner SMEP Microfinance Bank. She has applied for a 50,000 KES loan to buy more flour, soda, bread and other groceries to sell. Her business goal is to open another shop within the next five years.

loans.use: to buy more flour, soda, bread and other groceries to sell.

loans.name: Nahai Group

texts.en: Khampong is excited the filter was available on an affordable, payment plan.  Khampong and his group, along with other villagers, participated in a village meeting where they discussed the costs of treating local water supplies.  Charcoal, firewood, even bottled water were discussed and priced out over 2 years.  The water filter Khampong and his group purchased is guaranteed for 2 years but is known to function for up to 5 years.  Khampong and his group also discussed the cost of medical care for water-borne disease. And after totaling up the costs, Khampong and his group recognized the substantial financial savings the water filter will have for them and their families..

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters so they can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna is from Aygehovit village where she lives with her husband, son and daughter. Her son is an army officer and the other family members help Susanna with farming business. They are involved in aviculture, livestock keeping and land cultivation. Susanna and her family also collect berries in summer season and sell them in the market.

To be able to make an investment on the farm, Susanna asks this loan. She plans to purchase a grape orchard and start the cultivation of grapes. As this is Susanna's first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance-loan program provides loans to people who don’t have access to credit products before, because they have no credit history.

The loan that Susanna has requested will help her to enlarge her farm and her family will have a chance to have more income.

loans.use: to buy a grape orchard and expand her farming activity for family income.

loans.name: Phanith

texts.en:
Phanith is 45 years old and married. She lives in Takeo province with her family. Four out of six dependent children are in still in school. To make a living, Phanith and her husband earn main source of family income by growing rice and raising pigs. Moreover, they raise cows and organize wedding tents to earn supplemental income. Having been involved in these businesses for years, they earn around USD15 per day and can save approximately about USD3 each day after daily expenses. Lack of experience in raising pigs and insufficient water to supply in farmland were the challenges to her.

Phanith has been with VisionFund for four times already and past loans has helped her to timely support her family’s needs. She will use her loan to buy piglets to raise and to repair the pigsty. She hopes that she can earn more income to keep her children in school until they graduate.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise and to repair the pigsty to get more income, so that she can keep her children in school.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
As a farmer generation, Chan living with wife and 2 children, continues his family business. He is a hard working farmer, so he always gets up early to prepare his equipment to do farming. He puts all his effort in order to make his family live in better condition.

He does not have electricity. His current power won’t make him achieve his goal. It is a money and time consuming. He has to go to charge a car battery every 2 or 3 days. After he found out that solar energy is the source he needs, he decided to apply for a Kiva loan to pay for good quality solar home systems. He believes solar home system can reduce his burden and make him achieve his goal.

loans.use: to pay for solar home system

location.town: Koh Trong Village, Koh Trong Commune, Kratie Distr

loans.name: Chrispus

texts.en:
Chrispus is well known farmer mainly dealing in tea farming in Kigondo village, Busheny District. He started this project in 2006 and he has managed to sustain his wife and two year old child. His side income is coffee farming and this has helped him earn some good money to support his family.

This is his second loan cycle from UGAFODE MDI and he is borrowing a loan of shs 2,000,000 to buy fertilizers for manuring his tea estate to increase the yields and family sustainability. He is an honest man at work, in his business and he works for 8 hours a day. He appreciates the Kiva contribution.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer for his tea estate.

loans.name: Vahram

texts.en:
Vahram lives with his wife and two little children in Agarak town. He is involved in agribusiness.
Vahram currently keeps a livestock of two cows and three calves. His wife helps him to get milk, make dairy products and sell it in the market.

Vahram asks this loan to purchase forage for feeding the livestock during coming cold seasons. Vahram took a loan from a local financial institution before and was unable to repay it, due to his weak financial situation and his unemployment. But after years of tireless work, Vahram has been able to find a good job as a laborer in the local factory and owns a farm, which is profitable enough to cover monthly payments.

Now, Vahram has been approved for a loan, within the framework of joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products.

loans.use: to pay for forage for feeding the livestock during coming cold seasons.

loans.name: Azmat

texts.en:
Two years ago Azmat started a small junior school to impart education in a marginalized community. Today there are 88 students in her school, the majority of which are females. Azmat believes that a comfortable environment for students is important to ensure learning.

She has decided to buy a generator for the school where electricity shortage is a constant issue. For this purpose she needs Rs 80,000 part of which she wants to invest in a small amount of school furniture. Azmat aims to improve the quality of education in her school and is committed to achieving this through hard work and commitment.

loans.use: to buy a generator for her junior school, where electricity shortage is a constant issue and to invest in a small amount of school furniture.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne is a single woman with 1 child. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes and has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital.

She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future, she will expand her business. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.es:
Mujeres Unidas se llama este grupo está en su ciclo número 1 del programa de comité de mujeres, están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza, para poder conocer la situación de vida de cada una, y conforme a ello poder mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de sus familias.
La Sra. Rogelina pide este préstamo para poder comprar pescados variados para la venta, y así seguir con ese negocio que tiene, el cual es la venta de pescados. Ella es una mujer muy trabajadora que poco a poco ha ido creciendo por medio de su trabajo y su lucha diaria.
Rogelina agradece por la oportunidad que está recibiendo de poder seguir ayudando a su familia por medio de su trabajo.
texts.en:
This group, called "United Women," is presently in its first cycle in the program offered by the Women's Committee. The members are carrying out an inquest and by doing so, they will learn the life situation of each member. Their aim is to eliminate poverty and to improve the conditions of life of themselves and their families.

Rogelina requested the loan so that she could purchase a variety of fish to sell, thereby continuing with her fish-mongering business. She is a very hard-working woman who, little by little, has grown due to her work and her daily struggle.

Rogelina is grateful for the opportunity she is receiving of being able to continue helping her family by means of hard work.

loans.use: purchase a variety of fish to sell.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos es un hombre con 36 años de edad, casado y tiene 7 hijos menores, la adversidad que lo ha perseguido no ha sido obstáculo para querer salir adelante y alcanzar sus metas.
Con este negocio ha tenido un gran progreso, con los ingresos obtenidos ha logrado pagar sus deudas y cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar.

Carlos actualmente se encuentra solicitando un préstamo el cual lo invertirá en la compra de 6 novillas, con esto espera aumentar sus ventas y de tal manera sus ganancias.
Su meta es continuar con su trabajo y en un futuro llegar a generar empleo a las personas que más lo necesiten.

Sus deseos de salir adelante y su actitud positiva permiten ver en este hombre unas ganas inmensas de superarse y por supuesto una respuesta favorable a su petición.
texts.en:
Carlos is 36 years old, married, and has seven minor children. Constant adversity has not prevented him from wanting to get ahead and achieve his goals. His business has allowed him to advance, and the income he has made from it has allowed him to pay off his debts and cover his household's basic needs.

Carlos is currently requesting a loan to invest in purchasing six heifers. He expects to increase his sales through this purchase so that his profit also increases.

His goal is to keep working and to one day be able to generate employment for people who need work. His drive to get ahead and his positive attitude show that this is a man who is driven to improve himself and worthy of approval.

loans.use: to buy six heifers.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 57 years old with five grown children. She lives in Ormoc City with her family. Diana is dependent in her small restaurant, locally known as a "carenderia", and her vegetables selling business for an income. Because of these businesses that she needs to have an additional capital so she can invest more. She is asking a loan to buy more vegetables like bitter gourd, bottle gourd, cabbage, bell pepper, meat for barbecue, seasoning and food for the family. Diana hope to save in the future so she can live comfortably.

loans.use: to buy bitter gourd, bottle gourd, cabbage, bell pepper, meat for barbecue, seasoning and food for the family

loans.name: Sandra Elizabeth

texts.es:
Sandra, vive con su linda familia integrada por su esposo y dos hijos con edades de 6 y un año de edad, su manera  actual de obtener recursos económicos para apoyar en los gastos familiares es vender prendas de vestir para ambos sexos y diferentes edades, lo hace desde aproximada mente 2 años y con un horario de nueve de la mañana a cuatro de la tarde, lo inicio con capital propio.
Para mantener el ritmo de las ventas necesita de un crédito con el que comprara blusas, faldas, pantalones, camisas y otro tipo de prendas de vestir, así retener a sus clientes y ofrecerles estilos nueva de mercadería, espera tener un negocio más competente y generar más ingresos.
Sus aspiraciones son crecer con su negocio y darle una mejor vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Sandra lives with her family: her husband and their two children, who are ages six and one. Her current means of earning income in order to contribute to covering her family's expenses is by selling clothing items for men and women of all ages. She has been doing this for about two years and her work schedule is from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm. She started her business with her own capital.

In order to increase sales, she needs a loan to buy blouses, skirts, pants, shirts, and other types of clothing items. This will allow her to retain her customers and to offer them new styles of merchandise. She hopes to build a more competitive business and generate more income. She wants her business to grow and to give her family a better life.

loans.use: to buy blouses, skirts, pants, shirts, and other clothing items.

loans.name: Melwisa

texts.en:
Melwisa is a married woman who has three children and resides in Baki, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur, Philippines. Melwisa helps her husband to manage and operate their farm land. They plant and harvest corn to sell to earn a living. She has been in this business for many years.

She joined Gata Daku MPC to have access to financial services that can help her improve her business. Recently, she requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to cover the cost of farm cultivation and fertilization. In the future, Melwisa wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to cover the cost of farm cultivation and fertilization

loans.name: Joseline Patricia

texts.es:
Joselin, vive en casa familiar con sus padres y dos hermanos, es soltera, no tiene hijos, se dedica a estudiar y a atender un negocio para costear sus gastos personales y de sus estudios, tiene como negocio la venta de cosméticos, ropa, joyería de enchape y edredones, lo hace desde casi 8 años, trabaja en su tiempo libre después de cumplir con la jornada de clases, el oficio lo aprendió con ayuda de su familia, su dificultad es que no tiene un horario fijo para trabajar. 
Con el crédito básicamente comprara edredones y joyería de enchape para cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes, el objetivo es mantener su negocio funcionando y que su situación financiera sea más estable, no representa riesgos, ya que trabaja mediante encargos previos de sus clientes y sus productos no son perecederos.
Sus sueños son continuar trabajando para culminar su carrera en medicina y apoyar a su familia.
texts.en:
Joselin lives at home with her parents and two siblings. She is single and doesn't have any children. She is going to school and also runs her own business in order to cover her personal expenses and pay for school. She works selling cosmetics, clothing, plated jewelry, and quilts. She has been doing this for nearly eight years. She works on her time off, after attending her classes, and learned the trade from her family. Her main challenge is that she doesn't have a fixed schedule to work.

She will use this loan to buy mostly quilts and plated jewelry to fulfill her customers' orders. She wants to keep her business going in order to have a more stable financial situation. She doesn't incur any risks, since she works filling orders made by her customers in advance and her products aren't perishable.

Her goal is to keep working in order to finish medical school and support her family.

loans.use: to buy quilts and plated jewelry.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
El Señor Victor es un cliente antiguo que trabaja en conjunto con la fundación paraguaya, el lucha y se esfuerza para poder seguir creciendo y mejorando cada día.
Comenta que tiene una playa de autos, y que por medio de su trabajo tiene los medios para una vida digna, el pide este préstamo para poder invertirlo en mantenimiento de algunos autos para la venta. Agradece por esta oportunidad que recibe de poder crecer y salir adelante.
texts.en:
Victor is a repeat customer who works together with Fundación Paraguaya. He fights and makes an effort to continue to grow every day.

He tells that he has a used car lot, and that because of his work he has the means to have a decent standard of living. He asks for the loan to be able to invest it in the maintenance of some cars to be sold. He is thankful for the opportunity he is receiving to be able to grow and get ahead.

loans.use: to do maintenance on vehicles for sale.

loans.name: Lewis

texts.en:
Lewis is a single man who describes himself as determined. He operates a retail business where he sells electronics. He has been involved in this business for four years.

Lewis' business is located in a strategic place and his primary customers are locals. He will use the KES 80,000 loan to buy more electronics.

His business goal is to own a supermarket within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be successful. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to puchase additional stock

loans.use: to buy more electronics.

loans.name: Melvin Sr.

texts.en:
Melvin supports his family by running a sari-sari (variety) store business. He has been doing this for almost 20 years.

Besides his sari-sari store business, he also raises pigs. He is asking for a loan to buy grocery stock such as canned goods, noodles, spices, toiletries, chips, candies, biscuits, coffee, sugar and soft drinks. He also will use the loan to buy piglets and feed.

In the future, Melvin dreams of having enough money to send all of his children to college and earn degrees.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, noodles, spices, toiletries, chips, candies, biscuits, coffee, sugar and soft drinks for his store and piglets and feed for his farm.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a married mother of four children. She describes herself as obedient. She operates a retail business where she sells cereals, onions, cabbages, and potatoes. Alice has been involved in this business for three years. Her primary customers are locals.

Alice describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the KES 25,000 loan to buy more cereals and vegetables. Her business goal is to own a big cereals store within five years.

Alice hopes that in the future, she will educate her children. This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more cereals and vegetables.

loans.name: Surja Maya

texts.en:
Surjamaya is 60 years-old, married and has four children. Many years ago, she established her meat shop business. Working seven days a week and five hours a day, she supports her family.

Surjamaya has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy chickens for her shop.

In the future, Surjamaya plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. In Nepal, the meat is always fresh. In small stalls along busy roads, open air butcher shops sell chicken, goat, and water buffalo by the kilo. The stalls are piled high with product and sales are brisk.

With the help of a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase additional stock at better prices. This increase in purchasing volume creates greater profit margins for the borrower.

loans.use: to buy chickens.

loans.name: Decelyn

texts.en:
Decelyn has been running her grocery store business for the past five years. She has gained more income than what she had expected to earn.

Decelyn is able to send her children to school and provide for the family's needs. She also was able to pay her previous obligation to GDMPC.

She wants to expand her business with a loan to buy more goods to sell. She will increase her income to pay for the education of her children up through college.

Decelyn’s plan for her future is to save money to sustain her family's daily needs and to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell.

loans.name: Sajhana

texts.en:
Sajhana, 38 years old, is married and has three children. Many years ago, She established her grocery shop business. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy grocery goods. In the future, Sajhana plans to uplift her family's economic condition. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods

loans.name: Shadrack

texts.en:
Shadrack is a married man. He has four children. He describes himself as being honest.

He operates a shoeshine business. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in a busy area, and his primary customers are mostly men. He describes his biggest business challenge as inadequate working capital.
